newsitem.title: UK: South African scientists revive frozen rat heart.
newsitem.headline: South African scientists revive frozen rat heart.

text.p: South African scientists have successfully frozen and revived a rat's heart, raising hopes that organs can be frozen to await transplant, New Scientist magazine reported on Thursday.

Michelle Visser and colleagues at the University of Pretoria used a special cryoprotectant chemical and froze the rat's heart to minus 196 C (minus 350 F), then gradually brought it back to normal temperature and started it beating again.
The thawing process starts by putting the heart into a solution, at the freezing point of water, that approximates the rat's natural body fluids.
They demonstrated their novel process at the laboratories of the Alcor Life Extension Foundation in Phoenix, Arizona, which partly paid for the research.
They are keeping the formula of the cryoprotectant liquid secret until they publish their results in a scientific journal in November.
Visser's group said they had also used their process on livers, kidneys and even rat brains.
"It's quite possible one day we will be transplanting frozen organs into humans," she told New Scientist.
